DOCNAME: SPASESKI AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Erik Møse;Julia Laffranque;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: The present application invokes a total of CARDINAL applicants . Their personal details are set out in the annex to this decision . All applicants are NORP nationals . All applicants were represented before the ORG by Mr B. Šokoski , with the exception of PERSON and PERSON GPE , who were represented by PERSON , both lawyers practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The first , second , third , fourth , eighth and ninth applicants are former employees of the private company ORG , and the remaining applicants of the private company ORG ( “ the former employers ” ) . They all brought civil actions against the former employers claiming payment of employment - related benefits , namely DATE - leave allowance ( регрес за годишен одмор ) , food ( хранарина ) and travelling allowances that they had not received during their employment ( “ the reference period ” ) . The only exception was that the first , second and third applicants did not claim payment of the travelling allowance . All claims were submitted to ORG . The ORG cases were finally decided by ORG with decisions rendered DATE and DATE . The relevant facts concerning the applicants’ claims , the reference period and the outcome of the domestic proceedings are contained in LAW , CARDINAL and CARDINAL below :
Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides that employees’ rights are regulated by law and collective agreements .
Under LAW , ORG is the highest court , providing for the uniform application of laws by courts .
Under LAW , employment - related issues were regulated by this LAW or other laws and collective agreements .
Section CARDINAL of this Act provided that an employer could not take any action or decision restricting employment - related rights regulated by the LAW , law and collective agreements .
Under section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE LAW , employees were entitled to food and travelling allowances .

Under section CARDINAL , proceedings that were pending when this Act entered into force would be completed in accordance with the law valid at the relevant time , unless the present Act was more favourable for the employee .
This Act entered into force DATE after it was published in the “ ORG ” on DATE ( section CARDINAL ) .

Under section CARDINAL of LAW , the plenary session of ORG could adopt general legal opinions in order to ensure the uniform application of laws by the courts . The opinions were binding for all panels of ORG . The same provision appears in section CARDINAL § § CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of LAW .
Section CARDINAL of the then valid ORG provided for DATE - leave , food and travelling allowances .
Sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG provided for and specified the amount for DATE - leave , food and travelling allowances .
Section CARDINAL of ORG on the graphic and paper production industry provided for and specified the amount for annualleave , subsistence and travel allowances .

( a ) On DATE ORG , in proceedings following a legality review request submitted by the public prosecutor , found that the employer in the case was not allowed to restrict the payment of the food allowance . That the allowance had not been paid to the claimant ’s colleagues did not mean that he was not entitled to obtain that allowance ( Gzz.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) .

( b ) On DATE the civil department of ORG adopted a “ conclusion ” according to which , inter alia , if a trade union disagreed with an employer ’s decision restricting the payment of the food and DATE - leave allowances , courts were required to establish the facts regarding the employer ’s financial situation for DATE .

( c ) On an unspecified date in DATE , a joint opinion of the civil departments of all ORG in the respondent ORG at the time ( GPE , GPE and PERSON ) was published in ORG ( PERSON ) . According to this opinion , in case of reduced working hours due to employer ’s business losses an employee was entitled to obtain the full amount of the annual - leave allowance .

( d ) On DATE ORG , in proceedings following a legality review request submitted by the public prosecutor , dismissed a claim for the payment of DATE - leave allowance on account of the employer ’s business losses in the reference period ( PERSON ) . ORG decided likewise in another case where a legality review request had been submitted by the public prosecutor ( Gzz.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ) .

( e ) On DATE the civil departments of all CARDINAL ORG adopted a “ conclusion ” according to which courts were required , in cases concerning the payment of food and DATE - leave allowances , to establish facts concerning the ORG financial situation .

( f ) In “ conclusion ” dated DATE and CARDINAL DATE , the civil department of ORG stated that after the entry into force of the DATE LAW , courts should accept claims for the payment of the employment - related allowances specified in CARDINAL of that LAW ( see above ) irrespective of the employer ’s financial situation . The only exception was the annual - leave allowance .

The applicants submitted copies of several final decisions rendered before DATE in which the same first- and second - instance courts had accepted similar claims by the applicants’ colleagues ( P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; ORG ; P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ; and P.no.CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . The Government also submitted copies of other decisions of the domestic courts , including the first- and second - instance courts , adopted after DATE . All these cases concerned claims for the payment of the same employmentrelated allowances against the former and other employers . In these cases , the courts accepted claims for the payment of food and travelling allowances for reference periods that post - dated the entry into force of the DATE LAW irrespective of the employer ’s financial situation at the relevant time . The acceptance of identical claims for reference period that pre - dated the entry into force of that LAW was dependent on the employer ’s financial situation . This was also the case with claims concerning the payment of the annual - leave allowance , irrespective of the reference period . According to the ORG , such practice was in compliance with both ORG decision of CARDINAL DATE and the “ conclusions ” of ORG and DATE ( see above ) .
